Fun fact:
'natural' pearls are only coveted because they are so rare. When a 'natural' pearl is formed it can come from any type of foreign body entering the oyster.. but the resulting pearl will almost always NOT be (near to perfectly) round in shape.

Pearls that come from oyster farms are always round because they found a way for oysters to consistently create round pearls.. and they do this by manually inserting a tiny slab of bodymass from ANOTHER oyster into the oyster.

"But these cultured pearls aren't nearly as valuable as their rare natural counterparts."

Even though they're physically the exact same thing, somehow the pearls found in oysters torn from their natural habitats and forcefully pried open for harvest, are more valuable than the pearls found in the oysters raised in farms, that have nothing better to do with their lab mouse lives.

Like artificial diamonds, which are less valuable because they have fewer flaws, regardless of the horrible unethical things that are done to acquire "real" diamonds, (I air quote as if there's any way latticed carbon structures could ever not be genuine latticed carbon structures.) value seems to be placed on just how difficult and unethical the process was for the item to be obtained, rather than the efficiency of crafting or quality of the product.

Arbitrary value is arbitrary.

Eye strain.

It's actually called motion sickness. When feeling motion but not seeing it (for example, when sitting in a car and reading a book), the inner ear transmits to the brain that it senses motion, but the eyes tell the brain that everything is still. As a result of the discordance, the brain will come to the conclusion that one of them is hallucinating and further conclude that the hallucination is due to poison ingestion. The brain responds by inducing vomiting, to clear the supposed toxin.

Because what you see and what your body is doing doesn't match. Your body sits still in a car, but your eyes can clearly see that the world around you is moving. The opposite happens in a boat. Your body clearly feels like its moving, but since your in a mostly empty space (the ocean) your eyes doesn't think your moving. The brain realizes that there's something wrong, and thinks you've been poisoned, and wants you to vomit to get rid of the poison.

bigger is not better, we stop growing because our DNA tells us to (though some things like ears and noses actually continue growing for as long as we live). basicaly, there is little or no evolutionary benefit to be any bigger than what we are, it will not make us more likely to survive, it will not make us give birth to healthier children, it will not make us breed more, so evolution doesn't  favor infinite growth. note that big bodies may be able to gather food faster, but also need more food.

not all people do, for example people that were born deaf do not "hear" a voice in their heads, just as a born blind person can not "see" mental pictures, mentally talking to ourselves comes from the fact that hearing the word "apple" triggers neurons which correspond to your concept of an apple, thus when you think of the concept of an apple, it is extremely similar to when you hear someone say "apple", so the thinking of concepts triggers your brain to "hear" things that aren't there.

Well, that's the result of the negative image effect. Sunlight or bright light are commonly white light. When it goes to your eyes, they make the negative image effect, so from white light in will be negative which is black.

From what I understand, cultured pearls are made by putting a bead in the mollusk, and the mollusk then creates only a thin coating of nacre around the bead. Natural pearls are almost entirely nacre and are very rarely perfectly spherical. The only way to tell them apart is by x-raying them.

It would be difficult to tell by eye, as they are made by essentially the exact same process. But with X-ray examination, it can be determined. Harvesters generally place a 'bead' inside of mollusks which triggers the pearl response. Not only does this bead help the pearl to be spherical (because not all pearls are evenly shaped), its structure looks much different when X-rayed. Specifically, natural pearls show concentric growth rings, while cultured show a solid centre (because of the bead)
